instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
Out of a 2017 MBP. No history on board.

<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and surrounding does show some signs that someone before me had attempted some repair.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.04V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0


Suggestions on where to start?

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
Really no voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>, with charger alone?
How do you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> then?
Strange to have 13V from battery alone.

If is the case, disconnect the battery, work with the board alone on the desk.

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> - 0v 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.04

This is with board out , no battery attached.

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> comes from <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>; if no battery present.
There must be at least 5V!!!
Please get a better test point for <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>; just to confirm.

We cannot help if you do not provide accurate information.

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
Sigh. My voltmeter took a dump. Haha. New voltmeter in hand.

New readings 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.0v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 20.3v

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
Please, put a bit more effort.
Check coils voltage.
What about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
We discussed so many times about power on sequence (on the forum); which signals did you check???

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 8.5V

My apologies. Not really used to the newer stuff. Power alias a tad confusing

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 8.5V"
This is really strange, change <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>.
Post diode mode to ground at L7670/90.

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message: Will do. I will update tomorrow.

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
I am at a bit of a loss. Before replacing <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> today I powered on the board to do some more tests quick. 

Next thing you know I smell electrical and it appears <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> fried. No idea why. Anyways, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now gone and short to ground. Can this BGA chip even be replaced?

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message:
Can be changed, of course.
Pay atention, do not stress the board too much (with heat).

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message: I did some searching and could not find that chip available. At least in the united states.

threads.title: 840-00840-a No Power
threads.message: Buy scrap boards from Aliexpress, is the best option to make stock.
